title.narrative: Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development (ORD), Marshall Aid Commemoration Commission

description.narrative: This project supports the efforts of the British government to conduct the EPA-Cooperative Marshall Scholars Programme, which provides opportunities for US students with excellent academic records to pursue up to 5 years of graduate level work leading to a PhD or equivalent degree in an environmental field with global or international significance, studying, for example, international collaborative approaches to solving challenges of clean air, clean water, and environmental stewardship. The first 2 years of this study are to be conducted at a university in the UK at the expense of the British government. EPA pays for the final 3 years of the scholarship, either in the UK or US.

person-name.narrative: Glen Cuscino and April Bullock; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR), EPA-WHO Collaborative Effort to Protect Human Health and the Environment

description.narrative: The objective of this cooperative agreement is to support the work of the World Health Organization (WHO), which is of value to the international scientific community and nations of the world. It implements a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the EPA Administrator and Director General of WHO, signed first in 1992 and then in 2002. The activities under this agreement contribute to the protection of human health and the environment by linking existing institutions and personnel to work on shared goals including sound environmental management, improved human health risk reduction from environmental hazards, pollution prevention and sustainable economic development.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Environmental Protection Agency, Environmental Programs and Management

title.narrative: Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR), EPA-WHO Collaborative Effort to Protect Human Health and the Environment

description.narrative: Through its Federal Guidance authority, EPA is responsible for providing guidance to health care facilities on radiation protection standards and practices. The World Health Organization is using funds from EPA to develop an educational tool for medical professionals in an effort to reduce unnecessary exposure from pediatric imaging. Improved digital imaging techniques such as computed tomography have been accompanied by a dramatic rise in medical doses to the public. These funds will be used for physician pilot testing and feedback and to develop supporting outreach materials.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Environmental Protection Agency, Environmental Programs and Management

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR): Capacity Building and Technical Assistance on Clean and Efficient Cooking Practices

description.narrative: An estimated 1.5 million people die prematurely each year from breathing dangerous levels of indoor smoke from cooking with solid fuels in open fires and unvented stoves. During 2002 - 2012, the Partnership for Clean Indoor Air (PCIA) improved health, livelihood and quality of life by increasing the use of clean, efficient, affordable, reliable and safe home cooking/heating technologies and fuels in developing countries. Activities included: building the capacity of the ~600 public and private partner organizations to meet community needs; develop local markets; improve technology performance; and monitor the health, social, economic, and environmental impacts of their interventions. In 2010, EPA helped launch the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves to expand the efforts and results of PCIA. The Alliance is led by the United Nations Foundation with support from several Federal Agencies, foreign governments and the private sector.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR): DW89923035

description.narrative: The Global Methane Initiative (GMI) is an action-oriented initiative that will reduce global methane emissions by promoting cost-effective, near-term projects that recover and use methane as a clean energy source. GMI is international in focus and will expand collaboration between developed countries, developing countries and countries with economies in transition, together with strong participation from the private sector. Founding partner countries account for approximately 60 percent of global methane from the targeted sources.

description.narrative: The Global Methane Initiative (GMI) is an action-oriented initiative that will reduce global methane emissions by promoting cost-effective, near-term projects that recover and use methane as a clean energy source. GMI is international in focus and will expand collaboration between developed countries, developing countries and countries with economies in transition, together with strong participation from the private sector. Founding partner countries account for approximately 60 percent of global methane from the targeted sources.

person-name.narrative: Glen Cuscino and April Bullock; Ryan Boles

description.narrative: The Global Methane Initiative promotes cost effective, near term methane abatement and recovery internationally through partnerships between developed and developing countries and with stron participation from the private sector, development banks and other governmental and non-governmental organizations, Methane abatement and recovery will provide significant strategic benefits in terms of addressing global climate change by reducing a potent greenhouse gas and utilizing a clean energy source.

description.narrative: An estimated 1.5 million people die prematurely each year from breathing dangerous levels of indoor smoke from cooking with solid fuels. This work is to support coordination and implementation of the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves to save lives, improve livelihoods, empower women, and protect the environment by creating a thriving global market for clean and efficient household cooking solutions. The Alliance is led by the United Nations Foundation with support from several Federal Agencies, foreign governments and the private sector.

description.narrative: Funding is provided to increase exchange of innovative technology, best practices and lessons learned, and to increase the capacity among organizations working in the air quality, health, and environmental sectors. title.narrative: Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR), Global Methane Pledge Implementation Support

description.narrative: To provide EPA with the technical, analytic, policy, and outreach support services to advance and enhance implementation of methane mitigation activities in support of the Global Methane Pledge. title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Enforcement and Compliance Assurance (OECA): Coop

description.narrative: This project promotes and strengthens international environmental enforcement through the advancement of four primary goals: (1) raising capacity, (2) exchange of environmental crime information, (3) operational support for member countries, and (4) communicate, network and exchange skills among law enforcement officers. The major work to be accomplished is the development of a program website, support of a climate change project which will ensure markets operate properly and fraud is detected promptly with regard to carbon trading, and strategies relating to an E-Waste project, which seeks to reduce the amount of environmental degradation resulting from disposal of electronic items, support of Project Clean Seas, and distribution and sharing of knowledge and techniques on an an Envirnomental Forensics Project.

description.narrative: It is estimated that millions of people die prematurely each year from breathing dangerous levels of indoor smoke from cooking with solid fuels in open fires and unvented stoves. During 2002 - 2012, the Partnership for Clean Indoor Air (PCIA) improved health, livelihood and quality of life by increasing the use of clean, efficient, affordable, reliable and safe home cooking/heating technologies and fuels in developing countries. In 2010, EPA helped the United Nations Foundation launch the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves to expand the efforts and results of PCIA.

description.narrative: The objective os this cooperative agreement is to stimulate/support the work of World Health Organization (WHO) and the Environment, including risk assessment, which is of value to the international scientific community and nations of the world. It implements a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the EPA Administrator and Director General of WHO, signed first in 1992 and then in 2002. The activities under the MOU and this agreement contibute to the protection of public Human Health and the Environment by linking together existing institutions and personnel to work on shared goals including sound environmental management, improved human health risk reduction of enviromental hazards, pollution prevention and sustainable economic development.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR): Requisition

description.narrative: EPA and the Shanghai Environmental Protection Bureau launched AirNow International in 2010, with real-time air quality data reporting from the 2010 World Expo. The Shanghai EPB used technology developed by EPA to send air quality data to Shanghai citizens through the Internet. EPA and Shanghai EPB unveiled AIRNow International at the Shanghai Expo in May 2010. In FY 12, EPA extended the AIRNow International system beyond Shanghai into neighboring Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces. Both are installing and configuring AirNow-I with release dates in the near future. Also in FY12, EPA began work on the third AirNow-I system in Monterrey, Mexico. EPA developed a forecast model for Sao Paulo, Brazil .

title.narrative: Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention (OCSPP), Good Laboratory Practice .On-site Evaluation Programme

description.narrative: The objective of this grant is to provide financial support to the work on Good Laboratory Practice (GLP) that complements the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Test Guidelines by setting quality standards for the organization and management of test facilities and for performing and reporting studies. Under the GLP programme the workgroup conducts on-site evaluation activity for each national GLP Compliance Monitoring Programme (CMP) in OECD every ten years. These evaluations enhance confidence that receiving authorities are provided accurate and complete assessments of the conduct of non-clinical health and environmental safety studies and of the quality of the data.

The effort will support work on test guidelines; the assessment of chemicals and nanomaterials; capacity building; biosafety; facilitation of risk reduction; chemical accidents and pollutant release and transfer registers.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR): Technical Support Contract: "Analysis of Ozone Depleting Substances and Substitutes"

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to reduce emissions of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), a group of potent GHGs used as alternatives to ozone-depleting substances in the refrigeration, air-conditioning, foam blowing industries, and other sectors. Activities will focus in key geographical regions, particularly Asia, where increased demand in equipment such as for refrigeration and air-conditioning increases potential emissions of high global-warming HFCs used as refrigerants. These activities will engage developing countries through workshops, meetings, and training opportunities to fully consider alternative technologies, policy options, and improve capacity to develop national or regional approaches to meet the objectives of avoided HFC emissions.

Founding partner countries account for approximately 60 percent of global methane from the targeted sources.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Enforcement and Compliance Assurance (OECA): Support for Secretariat of the International Network for Environmental Complinace and Enforcement

description.narrative: Funds go towards two activities: 1.) Cooperative Agreement with the Institute for Governance & Sustainable Development (IGSD) to provide Secretariat support for the International Network for Environmental Compliance and Enforcement (INECE). EPA provides support to INECE for the development of effective enforcement programs in other countries to improve the rule of law and good governance internationally, in order to better control global pollution that can effect the U.S. and provide a level playing field for U.S. companies competing in world trade. 2.) Cooperative Agreement with IGSD to support the Seaport Environmental Security Network (SESN) to enhance the ability of the worlds ports to stop illegal shipments of hazardous waste. For more information on INECE or SESN, visit: www.inece.org.

person-name.narrative: Glen Cuscino and April Bullock; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR): Grant - AAAS for Fellow to support initiatives that build developing country capacity to reduce or avoid HFC emissions

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to reduce emissions of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), a group of potent GHGs used as alternatives to ozone-depleting substances in the refrigeration, air-conditioning, foam blowing industries, and other sectors. Activities will focus in key geographical regions, particularly Asia, where increased demand in equipment such as for refrigeration and air-conditioning increases potential emissions of high global-warming HFCs used as refrigerants. These activities will engage developing countries through workshops, meetings, and training opportunities to fully consider alternative technologies, policy options, and improve capacity to develop national or regional approaches to meet the objectives of avoided HFC emissions.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of International and Tribal Affairs (OITA): Grant

description.narrative: The 10 Year Framework is an international effort agreed to by the United States and other UNEP member nations at Rio+20. The goal of the the Internatinal Partnership on Product Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) under the 10YFP is to enhance the accessibility of essential data for conducting product/commodity LCA, including through promoting interoperability of LCA databases globally, and collaboration on tools development to enhance applications, improve data access, and reduce costs of using LCA internationally.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of International and Tribal Affairs (OITA)

description.narrative: Supporting the Solving the E-Waste Problem (StEP) initiative to review current data around the world, apply the methodology, and produce information for E-Waste flows to and from developing countries similar to the STeP and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Materials Systems Laboratory and the US National Center for Electronics Recycling (NCER) study in order to make comparisons that can be incorporated in the E-waste World Map.

person-name.narrative: Glen Cuscino and April Bullock; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of International and Tribal Affairs (OITA)

description.narrative: Provide technical assistance and training to selected countries with which the United States has negotiated Environmental Cooperation Mechanisms (ECMs) in order to strengthen legal and regulatory environmental frameworks and effective enforcement of environmental laws (including natural resources related laws). In addition, to conserve biodiversity and improve management of protected areas and ecologically important ecosystems, which will lead to sustainable development and management of natural resources.

description.narrative: Demonstrate the economic, environmental, social, and public health benefits of greener urban investment strategies by leveraging and building on existing and planned event infrastructure investments, including those planned for the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics as well as initiatives being developed for Rio 2012

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention (OCSPP): Organisation for Economis Co-Operation & Develop

description.narrative: The grant focuses on multiple program areas under the OECD EHS program , including work on industrial chemicals, pesticides, biocides, biotechnology and nanotechnology. The OECDEHS program works to ensure high quality chemical testing and evaluationk, to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of chemical management, and to minimize non-tarriff barriers to trade in chemicals and products containing chemicals.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of International and Tribal Affairs (OITA)

description.narrative: In support of UNEPs Global Mercury Partnership, this investment will develop the guidance materials, including materials to support national governments to facilitate formalization or regulation of the sector, manage trade and prevent diversion of mercury to Artisnal Small Gold Mines (ASGM) from other uses, develop a public health strategy, and involve stakeholders. The Global Mercury effort has identified the need to develop a guidance document for preparing National Action Plans (NAPs) that are compliant with the requirements of the Minamata Convention.

title.narrative: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Air and Radiation (OAR): Capacity Building and Technical Assistance on Clean and Efficient Cooking Practices

description.narrative: An estimated 1.5 million people die prematurely each year from breathing dangerous levels of indoor smoke from cooking with solid fuels. This work supports capacity building and technical assistance to assist local organizations meet community needs; develop local markets; improve technology performance; and monitor the health, social, economic, and environmental impacts of their interventions. This work supports the mission of the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves.
